_header: Praising be to God at this beginning
Subjects: prologues; dedications; Humphrey, duke of Buckingham; Fastolf, John, sir
_description: Dedicatory prologue to Stephen Scrope’s version of Christine de Pisan’s Epitre d’Othéa (addressed to Humphrey, Duke of Buckingham or to Sir John Fastolf) — in couplets (with succeeding verse introductions to each of the 100 chapters, one quatrain for chap. VI and following)

CamStJohn208.First Lines:
Praisyng be to god at this begynnyngIn alle my wordes and soo
                    folowyng…
CamStJohn208.Last Lines:
…ffor a womman lerned AugustusTo be worshipid & taught him
                    þus
CamStJohn208.Note:
Prose ‘Glose’ and ‘Allegorie’ applied to last
                    ‘Texte’ continue to f. 60.
CamStJohn208.Attributed Title:
Prolouge of the pistell Othea (f. 1); Othea dedicated to the Duke of
                    Bockingham (added by later hand, f. iiv)
CamStJohn208.Editions:
Barratt,  Alexandra,
                        ed.  
             Women’s Writing in Middle English.
         London: Longman, 1992: 140-9 (excerpts).

Longleat253.Editions:
Warner,  Sir George Frederic,
                        ed.  
             The Epistle of Othea to Hector, or, The Boke of Knyghthode.
Roxburghe Club
         141. London: Nichols, 1904: 5-6 (and interspersed verse, passim).

PierpontM775.First Lines:
Othea of prudence manyd goddesseThat settith good hertis in
                    worthinesse…
PierpontM775.Last Lines:
…ffor a woman serued AugustusTo be worshipid & tauȝt
                    him thus
PierpontM775.Note:
With a dedication, formerly listed separately as 1371; prose ends f.
                        274v.
PierpontM775.Attributed Title:
Here begynneth th Pistill of Othea the goddesse whiche sent it to Hector
                    whan he was xv yere of age (f. 200v)
PierpontM775.Editions:
Bühler,  Kurt. 
             “The Revisions and Dedications of the Epistle of Othea.” 
             Anglia
         76 (1958): 266-70: 266).
